title: Home
text:
Welcome to my reflective e-portfolio documenting my learning journey across five key areas of academic and professional development.


This portfolio represents my self-assessment and development planning in:

Enterprise Authoring and Presentation Tools - Word, Excel, PowerPoint proficiency
Information Literacy - Research, searching, and source evaluation skills
Coding and Collaboration Platforms - Git, GitHub, and version control
Continuous Professional Development - Networking and career progression
Responsible Use of AI - Ethical AI integration and academic integrity

Each section includes: - Reflection: What I have learned, challenges faced, and key insights - Self-Assessment: My current level of mastery and areas for growth - Forward Plan: How I will achieve full mastery and connect it to my career




Name: Parminder Singh
Student ID: 25351400
Module: SQ4003 - Professional and Study Skills
Module Tutor: Kanthu Joseph Mhango
Submission Deadline: 15:00 on Thursday, 29 January 2026




Use the navigation menu above to explore each portfolio section.

Academic Integrity Declaration: I declare that this work is my own and meets the standards of academic integrity expected at Harper Adams University. Any AI usage has been acknowledged and used responsibly as a supportive tool only.

title: 1 Harper Adams University Assignment Brief
text:
Module Name (Module Code): Professional and Study Skills (SQ4003)
Module Tutor: Kanthu Joseph Mhango
Assignment Title: e-portfolio
Assignment Type: Individual Assignment
Time Guide: ~50 hours
Word/Page Limit: not applicable
File Type: Word doc with GitHub link (GitHub to contain various required file types)
File Size Limit: 50 MB
Student Name: Parminder Singh
Student ID: 25351400





Research and analyse literature relevant to data science, business, and engineering.
Develop web pages using GitHub and Markdown.
Utilise Excel for data analysis and management.
Implement basic programming concepts using Copilot and CLI.
Design and deliver effective presentations.





15:00 on 2026-01-29 (Thursday, 29th January)
Please ensure that your student number is included at the beginning of your submission title when uploading your work




AI usage is permitted in-line with University Guidance: - Acknowledge AI use alongside references - Use ethically and responsibly - You remain responsible for originality and academic integrity




In submitting this assignment:
I/we declare that the work is my/our own work and that it meets the standards of academic integrity expected at all times as set out in university academic integrity policy. I/we also confirm that this work conforms to the stated Artificial Intelligence guidance for this assignment brief and has not previously been submitted for assessment for an academic award, unless otherwise indicated.




Build a reflective e-portfolio documenting your learning across five key areas. For each section provide: - Reflection on what you’ve learned, challenges, and insights - Self-assessment of current mastery level - Forward plan for achieving mastery
Present as a GitHub Page built in Quarto.






Reflect on your experience using Microsoft Word, Excel and PowerPoint. Discuss:

Strengths and weaknesses of each tool for academic and professional use.
Examples of how you have used them so far.
The extent of AI integration in these tools for automating data entry.
Your current level of confidence, and what you need to improve to meet professional standards in written and visual communication.




Reflect on how to conduct effective academic and professional searches. Draw on your information literacy sessions to discuss:

How to use library catalogues, databases, and search strategies effectively.
A critique of the strengths and weaknesses of one method/model for formulating research questions that guide a literature review (e.g. PICO).
The importance of evaluating sources for credibility.
Your self-assessment of searching skills now, and how you plan to develop them further.




Reflect on your learning with Git, GitHub and GitHub Pages. Discuss:

How these platforms enable collaboration, version control, and public presentation of work.
A technical description of Git, including its data structures, commands and references.
Strengths and challenges you faced while using them.
How collaborative tools will fit into your academic journey and professional development.




Reflect on your responsibilities for CPD as a student and future professional. Discuss:

Joining professional networks (e.g. LinkedIn, professional societies).
Understanding your programme specifications and key academic milestones.
Identifying how these connect to achieving marketable graduate attributes.




Reflect on your understanding of artificial intelligence in academic and professional contexts. Discuss:

How to use AI responsibly and in line with university policies.
Avoiding plagiarism and ensuring originality in your work.
How you can prepare to engage critically with evolving AI policies in your future career.






Your report must include references in the Harvard Cite Them Right format.





✓ Github pages e-portfolio containing all deliverables from the task outline
✓ A docx document uploaded to Turnitin containing the github repository link







The work will be judged against the extent to which it fulfils the following criteria:



Criteria
Weighting




e-portfolio
100%












Mark Range
Criteria




90-100
Outstanding and error free overall, flawless, perfectly correct portfolio and analysis, clear text and reproducible, transparent methods, assumptions and motivation, perfect adherence to formatting and instructions. Evidence of synthesis and perception of complex concepts or ideas.


80-89
Outstanding otherwise, but some small imperfections possible. Evidence of synthesis and perception of complex concepts or ideas.


70-79
Excellent and clear overall. Some small errors possible. Clear, correct and reproducible throughout.


60-69
Very good to excellent throughout. All major concepts clear and correct and reproducible. Some errors or imperfections possible, or otherwise areas that can be improved in rigour, accuracy or justification.


50-59
Good to very good throughout and complete. There are some obvious errors or omissions that do not severely undermine the clarity.


40-49
Work that may be good in parts but with obvious major flaws that impede understanding or may be lacking important detail. The work may lack depth or have obvious omissions.


30-39
Poor work that may have some evidence of good potential, but lacks adherence to academic conventions, structure, adherence to guidelines, reproducibility, or relevance.


0-29
Poor, incomplete work that may lack adherence to academic conventions, structure, adherence to guidelines, reproducibility, or relevance.










Any part of your assignment that goes over the word count, page limit, or presentation time will not be marked. This is to make sure all students are assessed fairly and equally. It also helps you develop important skills in clear and focused communication.




Always try to upload your work at least 24 hours before the stated deadline.
Check that the uploaded digital copy is the correct version of the file – It is your responsibility to upload the correct file.
Incorrect files can be replaced without penalty before the deadline. After the deadline, replacing an uploaded file will incur a late penalty.
Retain a digital back-up of the assignment.
Retain copies of AI-generated materials.






Your feedback will be returned through GradeMark. To view feedback, please return to the drop-in box on your module. Instructions on how to access feedback through GradeMark can be found under the “Student Information” tab on the front page of The Learning Hub. As well as the grade/mark, you should also receive feedback (which may be typed or spoken) on your assignment. If the written feedback provided is unclear you are advised to contact the module leader/module tutor to provide clarification.
Your marked assignment should be returned by the date stated on the brief. If this will not be possible, the module leader/module tutor will advise students of the expected return date. If you do not receive your mark and feedback by this date, please ask your Course Tutor to contact the relevant Head of Department to advise them of this delay.




Work submitted after the published deadline will be subject to a mark penalty unless there are approved, documented, mitigating circumstances. The penalties for late or non-submission can be viewed here: [Insert link to university policy]







Date
Event




2025-10-06
Assignment launch to students


2026-01-29 (15:00)
Submission Deadline


2026-03-03
Feedback and grades returned



Assignment brief moderated by: Ed Harris

title: Continuous Professional Development (CPD)
text: This section is the reflection of my need to do continuous professional development (CPD) as the student and a future professional. It considers how ongoing learning, professional networking, and engagement with programme requirements support the development of employable graduate attributes (Baume and Popovic 2007).

title: Continuous Professional Development (CPD)
text: This section is the reflection of my need to do continuous professional development (CPD) as the student and a future professional. It considers how ongoing learning, professional networking, and engagement with programme requirements support the development of employable graduate attributes (Baume and Popovic 2007).

title: Continuous Professional Development (CPD)
text:
2 Reflection

2.1 What I Have Learned
I have developed an understanding of CPD as a lifelong process that requires active planning and self-regulation (Zimmerman 2002). The most important avenues of learning are ensuring that I remain relevant and up to date in my area of specialty, network articles, and developing skills in relation to the aspects of my career path.


2.2 Professional Networks
CPD is mainly centered on professional networking. I renew LinkedIn to have a professional profile, to access educational materials, as well as communicating with peers and people in the industry. Another way through which I have communicated with fellow professionals to widen my understanding of industry expectations is acquiring other pertinent professional societies and online communities such as webinars and conferences.
Programme and Employability The workforce needed to become familiar with the modifications in programmes and how the workforce is to be employed.
An option to programme milestones and learning outcomes has assisted me to determine pertinent graduate attributes and development spheres. Some of the activities such as work experience, internships, and skills-oriented programs have supported my knowledge in the expectations of the employers and career opportunities.


2.3 Challenges
Key challenges include balancing academic commitments with CPD activities, building confidence in networking, and managing time effectively.

title: Continuous Professional Development (CPD)
text:
3 Self-Assessment

3.1 Current CPD Capability
Self-assessed level (novice → intermediate → advanced → expert):

Professional networking

Understanding degree requirements

Awareness of graduate attributes

Career planning

Current CPD activities include maintaining a LinkedIn profile, attending development events, and engaging with skills-building resources.

title: Continuous Professional Development (CPD)
text:
4 Forward Plan

4.1 Development Plan (Next 12 Months)

0–3 months: Update LinkedIn profile, join relevant professional societies, attend introductory events.

3–6 months: Build professional relationships, complete targeted development courses, clarify career goals.

6–12 months: Maintain regular networking activity, pursue internship opportunities, and develop a professional portfolio.

These actions support structured CPD and ongoing employability development.

title: Continuous Professional Development (CPD)
text:
5 References


Baume, David, and Carla Popovic. 2007. “Reflective Self-Assessment and Graduate Attributes.” Journal of Learning and Teaching 1 (1): 20–34.


Zimmerman, Barry J. 2002. “Becoming a Self-Regulated Learner: An Overview.” Theory into Practice 41 (2): 64–70. https://doi.org/10.1207/s15430421tip4102_2.

title: Information Literacy
text: This section is the reflective description of my information literacy growth in relation to my capability to do effective academic and professional searches, evaluate the sources and pose clear research questions to direct literature reviews. These competencies are central to academic practice and evidence-informed decision-making in higher education and professional contexts (Muir and Thomson 2023; JISC 2023).

title: Information Literacy
text: This section is the reflective description of my information literacy growth in relation to my capability to do effective academic and professional searches, evaluate the sources and pose clear research questions to direct literature reviews. These competencies are central to academic practice and evidence-informed decision-making in higher education and professional contexts (Muir and Thomson 2023; JISC 2023).

title: Information Literacy
text:
2 Reflection

2.1 What I Have Learned
Throughout my programme, I have developed a structured approach to locating, evaluating, and synthesising information from a range of academic and professional sources. Key areas of learning include:

Library databases and search strategies: I have learned to use subject-specific databases effectively, selecting appropriate keywords and controlled vocabulary to improve search precision and recall (Muir and Thomson 2023).
Boolean operators and query formulation: Applying Boolean logic (AND, OR, NOT) and advanced search filters has enabled me to refine searches and manage large result sets more efficiently.
Source evaluation and credibility assessment: I have developed greater awareness of criteria such as authorship, publication venue, methodology, and citation patterns when assessing the reliability and relevance of sources (Bloom and Weisberg 2020).
Literature review processes: I have learned to synthesise findings across multiple studies, identify themes and gaps in the literature, and position sources within an academic argument (Creswell 2018).

These skills have been applied in coursework and research tasks, improving the quality, coherence, and academic rigour of my written work.


2.2 Research Question Framework
To support structured inquiry, I have used established research question frameworks such as PICO (Population, Intervention, Comparison, Outcome), particularly when engaging with applied or evidence-based research (Sackett et al. 1996).

Strengths: The framework encourages clarity, focus, and alignment between the research question and search strategy, which supports systematic literature searching.
Weaknesses: PICO can be restrictive when applied to exploratory or qualitative research, where research questions may need to remain flexible and emergent.
Practical application: Using PICO has helped me translate broad topics into manageable research questions, improving the relevance and efficiency of database searches.

Engaging with such frameworks has reinforced the importance of methodological alignment between research questions, search strategies, and evaluation criteria (Creswell 2018).


2.3 Challenges and Insights
The greatest problem has been handling information overload especially when search results yield a great amount of information that is of different quality. Developing effective filtering strategies and applying critical evaluation criteria has been essential in addressing this issue (Muir and Thomson 2023).
Other complications consist of paywalled access to resources, time management when conducting the literature review. Reflective engagement with these challenges has highlighted the importance of self-regulated learning strategies, such as planning, monitoring progress, and adapting approaches when necessary (Zimmerman 2002).
Another important learning has been the realization that information literacy is not a one-time skill set that requires no further development, but a practice that must constantly be practiced through the continual development of tools, databases, and academic criteria.

title: Information Literacy
text:
3 Self-Assessment

3.1 Current Searching Skills Level
Self-assessed proficiency (novice → intermediate → advanced → expert):

Library database searching: Intermediate

Strengths: Keyword selection, use of filters, database navigation

Areas for development: Advanced subject headings and citation chaining

Source evaluation: Intermediate

Strengths: Assessing credibility, relevance, and methodological quality

Areas for development: Faster critical appraisal of complex studies

Research question formulation: Intermediate

Strengths: Structured frameworks, clarity of focus

Areas for development: Refining questions for qualitative and mixed-methods research


This self-assessment reflects the value of reflective self-evaluation in identifying strengths and areas for further development (Baume and Popovic 2007).


3.2 Skill Improvement
Since starting my programme, I have moved from relying on general web searches toward systematic use of academic databases, improved my ability to judge source quality, and gained confidence in shaping researchable questions that guide effective literature reviews.

title: Information Literacy
text:
4 Forward Plan

4.1 Development Plan (Next 3–12 Months)

Key skills to develop: Advanced database searching techniques, citation tracking, and critical synthesis of complex literature.
Academic and career relevance: Strengthening these skills will support dissertation work and enhance my ability to engage with evidence-based practice in professional contexts (Sackett et al. 1996).
Learning resources and workshops: Library-led training sessions, online research skills modules, and continued guided practice in academic writing.

This forward plan aligns with a growth-oriented approach to learning and supports the ongoing development of information literacy as a core graduate and professional attribute (Dweck 2006; JISC 2023).

title: Information Literacy
text:
5 References


Baume, David, and Carla Popovic. 2007. “Reflective Self-Assessment and Graduate Attributes.” Journal of Learning and Teaching 1 (1): 20–34.


Bloom, Paul, and Deena Skolnick Weisberg. 2020. “Childhood Origins of Adult Resistance to Science.” Science 316 (5827): 996–97. https://doi.org/10.1126/science.1133520.


Creswell, John W. 2018. Research Design: Qualitative, Quantitative, and Mixed Methods Approaches. 5th ed. Thousand Oaks, CA: SAGE Publications.


Dweck, Carol S. 2006. Mindset: The New Psychology of Success. New York: Random House.


JISC. 2023. “Digital Literacy Framework.” 2023. https://www.jisc.ac.uk/.


Muir, Stuart P., and Hugh E. Thomson. 2023. “Information Literacy Skills in Higher Education: A Systematic Review.” Journal of Academic Librarianship 49 (4): 102687. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.acalib.2023.102687.


Sackett, David L., William M. C. Rosenberg, Muir Gray, Richard B. Haynes, and W. Scott Richardson. 1996. “Evidence Based Medicine: What It Is and What It Isn’t.” BMJ 312 (7023): 71–72. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.312.7023.71.


Zimmerman, Barry J. 2002. “Becoming a Self-Regulated Learner: An Overview.” Theory into Practice 41 (2): 64–70. https://doi.org/10.1207/s15430421tip4102_2.

title: Enterprise Authoring and Presentation Tools
text: This part is a critical reflection on how I have used the Microsoft word, Excel and PowerPoint as enterprise authoring and presentation software in academic, and professional situations. It not only assesses my growing prowess in written, data-driven and visual communication, but also takes into account the growing impact of built-in artificial intelligence (AI) functionality on the formation of professional practice. The reflection is informed by scholarship on technology integration, digital literacy, and self-regulated learning in higher education (Richardson 2017; JISC 2023; Zimmerman 2002).

title: Enterprise Authoring and Presentation Tools
text: This part is a critical reflection on how I have used the Microsoft word, Excel and PowerPoint as enterprise authoring and presentation software in academic, and professional situations. It not only assesses my growing prowess in written, data-driven and visual communication, but also takes into account the growing impact of built-in artificial intelligence (AI) functionality on the formation of professional practice. The reflection is informed by scholarship on technology integration, digital literacy, and self-regulated learning in higher education (Richardson 2017; JISC 2023; Zimmerman 2002).

title: Enterprise Authoring and Presentation Tools
text:
2 Reflection

2.1 What I Have Learned
Through sustained academic use and coursework, I have developed foundational to intermediate proficiency across the Microsoft Office suite, aligning with recognised digital literacy frameworks that emphasise communication, information management, and collaboration skills (JISC 2023).

Microsoft Word: I have also understood how to format academic reports in terms of styles, headings, tables of contents, and references managers. These practices support academic writing conventions and improve clarity and consistency in formal texts, particularly in collaborative contexts (Norton, Brunas-Wagstaff, and Lockwood 2008).
Microsoft Excel: I have trained to enter structured data, use simple and intermediate formulas (e.g. IF statements, VLOOKUP/XLOOKUP) and also learned how to use pivot tables to summarise and analyse data. These skills support evidence-based reasoning and decision-making by enabling more systematic engagement with data (Sackett et al. 1996).
Microsoft PowerPoint: I have acquired skills on how to approach the design of a slide successfully, such as visual hierarchy, text concise, and in accordance with the expectation of the audience. These skills are essential for communicating complex ideas clearly in academic and professional settings (Cheshire 2013).

The competencies have been used in some coursework submission, group projects, and presentation, which have made a difference in my better clarity, consistency, and professionalism.


2.2 AI Integration
The growing adoption of AI functionality has impacted my enterprise tools usage to a great extent. Word has Microsoft Copilot which assists with drafting, summarisation, and revision, whereas Microsoft Excel contains AI-assisted applications that help to find patterns within datasets and propose methods of analysis. PowerPoint designer assists in the visual design and consistency.
From an educational perspective, such tools reflect broader developments in generative AI within learning environments, offering opportunities for efficiency while raising important pedagogical and ethical considerations (UNESCO 2023; Floridi and Cowley 2019). Although AI has enhanced productivity and saved on time used on mundane chores the technology has also posed the danger of over-dependence. Research on learning and cognition suggests that excessive automation may limit deeper engagement and conceptual understanding if not used reflectively (Bloom and Weisberg 2020).
Therefore, I have grown increasingly conscious of my application of AI as a secondary tool instead of a substitute of critical thinking, authorship, and design judgment.


2.3 Challenges and Insights
Some of the major ones as indicated above involve dealing with complicated format in long word files, learning of sophisticated excel features and handling team work where differences in practices may interfere with document quality. These challenges reflect broader issues identified in collaborative academic and digital work, where technical proficiency must be matched with shared standards and communication (Cheshire 2013).
Balancing automation with manual control has required reflective self-assessment, reinforcing the importance of metacognitive awareness in skill development (Baume and Popovic 2007; Zimmerman 2002). An important insight has been recognising that professional competence is not defined solely by familiarity with tools, but by the ability to apply them critically, ethically, and in contextually appropriate ways (Creswell 2018).

title: Enterprise Authoring and Presentation Tools
text:
3 Self-Assessment

3.1 Current Level of Mastery
Self-assessed proficiency (novice → intermediate → advanced → expert):

Word: Intermediate

Strengths: Document structure, referencing, collaboration tools

Weaknesses: Advanced layout control and long-document formatting

Excel: Intermediate

Strengths: Data organisation, basic analysis, pivot tables

Weaknesses: Advanced formulas, macros, and data visualisation

PowerPoint: Intermediate

Strengths: Clear slide design, visual consistency, audience focus

Weaknesses: Advanced animation and data-driven storytelling


This self-assessment aligns with reflective practice approaches that emphasise honest evaluation as a foundation for professional growth (Baume and Popovic 2007).


3.2 Skills Gap
To advance to the next level of proficiency, I should hone my think abilities in the Excel, ameliorate accuracy in composing lengthy internal records in word-processor, and the skill of using illustrations to express complicated data in Power point. Developing these skills supports higher-order cognitive processes, such as analysis and evaluation, as outlined in revised learning taxonomies (Krathwohl 2002).

title: Enterprise Authoring and Presentation Tools
text:
4 Forward Plan
The development plan will focus on sustaining the project and advancing it to the next phase.

Short term (3-6 months): Refreeze advanced Word formatting skills and improve the knowledge of Excel formulas by practicing and using structured tutorials.
Medium term (6-12 months): Build a greater level of skills in data analysis and presentation higher level charting and narrative style slide development.

This forward plan reflects a growth-oriented approach to skill development (Dweck 2006) and aligns with career goals by strengthening enterprise-level digital literacy, effective communication, and evidence-informed practice. The deployment of AI tools, the subsequent continuous practice, and reflection on such tools will promote the ongoing improvement of the professional development.

title: Enterprise Authoring and Presentation Tools
text:
5 References


Baume, David, and Carla Popovic. 2007. “Reflective Self-Assessment and Graduate Attributes.” Journal of Learning and Teaching 1 (1): 20–34.


Bloom, Paul, and Deena Skolnick Weisberg. 2020. “Childhood Origins of Adult Resistance to Science.” Science 316 (5827): 996–97. https://doi.org/https://doi.org/10.1126/science.1133520.


Cheshire, Coye. 2013. “Collaborative Research and the Digital Humanities: An Examination of Emerging Technological and Scholarly Practices.” SSRN Electronic Journal. https://doi.org/https://doi.org/10.2139/ssrn.2261536.


Creswell, John W. 2018. Research Design: Qualitative, Quantitative, and Mixed Methods Approaches. 5th ed. Thousand Oaks, CA: SAGE Publications.


Dweck, Carol S. 2006. Mindset: The New Psychology of Success. New York: Random House.


Floridi, Luciano, and Josh Cowley. 2019. “A Unified Framework of Five Principles for AI in Society.” IEEE Intelligent Systems 34 (3): 60–68. https://doi.org/https://doi.org/10.1109/MIS.2019.2928376.


JISC. 2023. “Digital Literacy Framework.” 2023. https://www.jisc.ac.uk/.

UNESCO. 2023. “Artificial Intelligence and Education: Guidance on Generative AI.” 2023. https://www.unesco.org/en/articles/ai-and-education.

title: Coding and Collaboration Platforms
text: In this section, I will present a reflective report on how I have learned and developed through the application of Git, GitHub and GitHub Pages as a piece of coding and collaboration platforms. It discusses how these tools facilitate version control, collaborative development processes and professional development of software and the technical concepts that it is based on. These platforms are widely recognised as foundational to collaborative digital work and software engineering (Spinellis 2005; GitHub, Inc. 2024).

title: Coding and Collaboration Platforms
text: In this section, I will present a reflective report on how I have learned and developed through the application of Git, GitHub and GitHub Pages as a piece of coding and collaboration platforms. It discusses how these tools facilitate version control, collaborative development processes and professional development of software and the technical concepts that it is based on. These platforms are widely recognised as foundational to collaborative digital work and software engineering (Spinellis 2005; GitHub, Inc. 2024).

title: Coding and Collaboration Platforms
text:
2 Reflection

2.1 What I Have Learned
Through coursework and practical experimentation, I have developed an understanding of both the practical and conceptual aspects of version control and collaborative development:

Git repositories and version control: I have learned how Git records changes over time, enabling safe experimentation, rollback, and transparent tracking of contributions (Spinellis 2005).
Git workflows and collaboration: I have used branching and merging to support parallel development, enabling multiple contributors to work on the same project without overwriting each other’s changes.
GitHub Pages publishing: I have learned to publish static websites directly from repositories, supporting portfolio development and public dissemination of work.
Command-line Git usage: Using Git via the command line has improved my understanding of core version control concepts and increased confidence in navigating development environments.
Applied projects: These skills have been applied in individual and group projects, reinforcing the connection between technical knowledge and real-world collaborative practice.



2.2 Technical Understanding
Developing technical literacy in Git has required understanding its underlying data model and operational logic:

Git data structures: Git stores data as objects, including blobs (file contents), trees (directory structures), and commits (snapshots of the project history). References, branches, and HEAD enable navigation and manipulation of project states (Spinellis 2005).
Essential commands: Core commands such as init, add, commit, push, pull, branch, merge, and clone support the full lifecycle of local and remote version control (GitHub, Inc. 2024).
Workflow model: Understanding the movement of changes from the working directory to the staging area, local repository, and remote repository has clarified how Git enforces deliberate and traceable change management.

This conceptual understanding has improved my ability to diagnose errors and resolve conflicts when they arise.


2.3 Collaboration and Challenges
Git and GitHub also have particularly important features related to collaborative work, such as a detailed record of changes, the possibility to roll back to an earlier version, and parallel development. These features are particularly valuable in collaborative and interdisciplinary projects, where transparency and accountability are essential (Cheshire 2013).
Nevertheless, there have been difficulties such as struggling with conflict management in merging, anxiety stemming when working on a command line and team coordination. The solution to these challenges has involved effective communication, similar conventions, and meditated problem-solving. This, over time, has made me confident about the value of working in a technical environment in which I collaborate with others, and the importance of a structured version control system.

title: Coding and Collaboration Platforms
text:
3 Self-Assessment

3.1 Git and GitHub Proficiency Level
Self-assessed proficiency (novice → intermediate → advanced → expert):

Git fundamentals (commit, push, pull, branch): Intermediate

Strengths: Consistent committing, version tracking, basic branching

Development areas: Advanced branching strategies and rebasing

Collaborative workflows: Intermediate

Strengths: Pull requests, merge resolution, shared repositories

Development areas: Workflow optimisation and large-team coordination

GitHub Pages and publishing: Intermediate

Strengths: Static site deployment, repository-based publishing

Development areas: Custom themes and automation

Understanding Git’s technical model: Developing → Intermediate

Strengths: Core object model and workflow concepts

Development areas: Internals, performance, and advanced history rewriting




3.2 Confidence in Version Control
I am confident working independently with Git and GitHub and increasingly confident contributing within teams. I am developing the ability to explain version control concepts to others, which reinforces my own understanding and supports collaborative learning (Baume and Popovic 2007).

title: Coding and Collaboration Platforms
text:
4 Forward Plan

4.1 Development Plan (Next 3–12 Months)

Months 1–3: Develop advanced branching strategies and contribute to open-source or shared projects to gain broader exposure to collaborative workflows.
Months 3–6: Learn continuous integration and deployment (CI/CD) pipelines and begin mentoring peers in version control practices.
Months 6–12: Consolidate advanced Git usage and explore DevOps concepts to strengthen industry relevance and professional portfolio development.

This forward plan aligns with professional software development expectations and supports the development of transferable collaboration and technical skills applicable across digital and interdisciplinary contexts.

title: Coding and Collaboration Platforms
text:
5 References


Baume, David, and Carla Popovic. 2007. “Reflective Self-Assessment and Graduate Attributes.” Journal of Learning and Teaching 1 (1): 20–34.


Cheshire, Coye. 2013. “Collaborative Research and the Digital Humanities: An Examination of Emerging Technological and Scholarly Practices.” SSRN Electronic Journal.


GitHub, Inc. 2024. “GitHub Docs: About Git.” 2024. https://docs.github.com/en/get-started/using-git/about-git.


Spinellis, Diomidis. 2005. “Version Control Systems.” In Proceedings of the 2005 International Conference on Software Engineering, 637–38. ACM.

title: Responsible Use of Artificial Intelligence
text: This section reflects on my understanding of artificial intelligence (AI) in academic and professional contexts, with particular emphasis on responsible use, academic integrity, and preparation for evolving institutional and workplace AI policies (Floridi and Cowley 2019; UNESCO 2023).

title: Responsible Use of Artificial Intelligence
text: This section reflects on my understanding of artificial intelligence (AI) in academic and professional contexts, with particular emphasis on responsible use, academic integrity, and preparation for evolving institutional and workplace AI policies (Floridi and Cowley 2019; UNESCO 2023).

title: Responsible Use of Artificial Intelligence
text:
2 Reflection

2.1 What I Have Learned
I have gained awareness of the features and its weaknesses of the latest AI assistants, including ChatGPT and Microsoft Copilot, and their possible usefulness in aiding learning and working endeavors. Use of these tools has demonstrated to be useful in both for efficiency and in explaining as well as the threats that come with its misuse or over use.
School Environment Research Responsible Provenience use in educational institutions.
Brainstorming, drafting assistance, concept explanation, code generating and data analyzing activities are some of the responsible academic uses of AI. Nevertheless, it is unacceptable to hand the work created by AI as my own without the process of learning or using the results without checking.
Responsible use has an aspect of transparency. That involves recognizing AI assistance when needed and adhering to institutional disclosure and referring directions.


2.2 Academic Integrity
AI contributes to the appearance of new types of threats to plagiarism, especially the generation of the text with passing off as original work. Distinguishing between AI as a support tool and AI as a content generator is essential, as academic responsibility remains with the student (Charmaz 2014). I have also got to know that any AI-based results should be assessed critically, examined, and brought into my scope of work in an ethical way.
Professional and Future Usage of AI.
Looking ahead, responsible AI use will be shaped by organisational policies, professional standards, and evolving regulation (JISC 2023). To be more precise, in the future, the need to develop AI literacy will become inevitable as it will allow using AI in a workplace consciously, ethically, and transparently.

title: Responsible Use of Artificial Intelligence
text:
3 Self-Assessment

3.1 Current AI Literacy
Self-assessed level (novice → intermediate → advanced → expert):

Understanding AI capabilities and limitations

Knowledge of university AI policies

Ability to use AI responsibly

Maintenance of academic integrity

I currently use AI tools selectively for idea generation, clarification, and productivity support, while ensuring compliance with academic requirements.

title: Responsible Use of Artificial Intelligence
text:
4 Forward Plan

4.1 Development Plan (Next 12 Months)

0–3 months: Review institutional AI guidance, practise safe and transparent use, understand declaration requirements.

3–6 months: Apply AI critically in assignments, strengthen evaluation skills, and explore discipline-specific AI tools.

6–12 months: Maintain up-to-date knowledge of AI developments, refine my ethical position, and prepare for professional AI use.

title: Responsible Use of Artificial Intelligence
text:
5 Key Takeaways

AI is a powerful support tool, but responsibility and authorship remain with the user.

Transparency and academic integrity are essential when using AI in education.

Ongoing AI literacy is critical for future professional practice.

title: Responsible Use of Artificial Intelligence
text:
6 References


Charmaz, Kathy. 2014. Constructing Grounded Theory. 2nd ed. London: SAGE Publications.


Floridi, Luciano, and Josh Cowley. 2019. “A Unified Framework of Five Principles for AI in Society.” IEEE Intelligent Systems 34 (3): 60–68. https://doi.org/10.1109/MIS.2019.2928376.


JISC. 2023. “Digital Literacy Framework.” 2023. https://www.jisc.ac.uk/.


UNESCO. 2023. “Artificial Intelligence and Education: Guidance on Generative AI.” 2023. https://www.unesco.org/en/articles/ai-and-education.
